Legal_Issue: Did the citizenship judge correctly apply the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: The applicant was short by 67 days of the required physical presence. The citizenship judge applied the Koo test, considering factors like property ownership and trips abroad.
Court_Ruling: The citizenship judge's decision was reasonable despite minor factual errors.
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet the three-year physical presence requirement within four years preceding application.
Assessment_Factor: Property ownership, trips abroad, normal residency indicators.
Evidence_Used: Evidence of travel history, property ownership, duration of absences.
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding the application.
Evidence_Assessed: Factors indicating normal residency, including ties to Canada and time spent abroad.
Governing_Rule: Residence interpreted as physical presence or normal residency based on contextual factors.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Shortfall of 67 days in physical presence.
Cause_Description: The applicant did not meet the residency requirement due to absences from Canada.
Evidence_Handling: Reviewed for normal residency criteria using the Koo test.
Residency_Compliance: Not met â€“ 67 days short of required physical presence.
Evidence_Assessment: Conducted via Koo test evaluating normal residency.
Decision_Rationale: The judge reasonably concluded the applicant was not normally resident in Canada.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in judicial review; Koo test for normal residency.
